misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Loop magically re-reads/updates input (reactive variable update)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that once they enter a guess into variable b before the loop, b will somehow change on its own during the while-loop as the program continues, or that the loop will "go back" to the earlier input statement automatically each iteration.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, variables do not update unless an assignment statement executes. A while-loop repeatedly executes only the statements inside its body; it does not automatically re-run code that appears before the loop. To get a new guess each iteration, the program must explicitly prompt and call s.nextInt() inside the loop (or at least assign to b inside the loop).
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Infinite loop (program repeatedly prints "Too low!" or "Too high!" forever) and the guess counter/output is incorrect relative to the intended game.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Counter/variable changes without the intended events (off-by-one due to mental model of when counting happens)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that incrementing c inside the loop correctly counts the number of guesses, including the first guess already read before the loop, or they’re thinking the loop represents "one guess" each time even though the first guess is outside it.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: Because the first input happens before the loop and c starts at 0, the first guess is not counted unless the guess is wrong (it only increments after entering the loop). Also, if the user guesses correctly on the first try, c remains 0 and the program reports 0 guesses. Correct counting requires either initializing c to 1 after reading the first guess, or incrementing immediately after each read, and (critically) reading a new guess inside the loop.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: can report 0 guesses for a correct first guess, and generally produces an incorrect guess count even aside from the infinite-loop issue.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that after printing 'Too low!' or 'Too high!', the loop will automatically re-evaluate the condition and somehow the user's next input will be incorporated without explicitly reading it again.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student has not included a statement to read the next guess inside the while loop. In Java, once a value is assigned to a variable, it does not change unless explicitly reassigned. The loop will infinitely repeat with the same value of `b` because there is no `b = s.nextInt()` statement inside the loop body. The student appears to believe that the loop condition check will somehow trigger reading new input, or that variables update automatically between iterations.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Infinite loop - the program will repeatedly print 'Too low!' or 'Too high!' forever without allowing the user to enter another guess.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that reading user input into a variable once (b = s.nextInt()) establishes a permanent link or a reactive relationship where the variable will automatically fetch a new value from the user whenever the loop condition is re-evaluated.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java's imperative execution model, the statement 'b = s.nextInt()' is an action that occurs exactly when the thread of execution reaches that line. It assigns the current value from the buffer to the variable 'b'. To update 'b' with a new guess from the user, the assignment must be explicitly repeated inside the loop body.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that the computer 'understands' that the prompt and input logic (lines 10-11) are part of the 'guessing process' and will automatically re-execute those lines because they are logically related to the while-loop condition.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: Java follows a strict sequential control flow. A while-loop only repeats the block of code enclosed within its curly braces {}. Code appearing before the loop is never implicitly re-run unless it is contained within an outer loop or a method call.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Self-updating input/loop state (expects variables to change without new code)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that once they read the first guess into `b`, the value of `b` will somehow change on later loop iterations (e.g., the loop will "ask again" automatically, or `Scanner` will keep supplying new values without an explicit read).
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, variables do not update unless your code assigns them a new value. A `while` loop only re-checks the condition; it does not automatically re-run input. To get a new guess each iteration, the program must explicitly prompt and execute `b = s.nextInt();` inside the loop (or at least once per iteration). Without that, `b` stays the same forever, so if the first guess is wrong the loop never terminates.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Infinite loop (prints "Too low!" or "Too high!" forever) and never reaches the "Correct!" message unless the first guess happens to equal `a`.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Counter updates automatically reflect “number of guesses” (off-by-one counting mental model)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes incrementing `c` only inside the loop is enough to report the total number of guesses, including the first guess made before the loop.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: `c` is only incremented when the loop body runs (i.e., only after a wrong guess). The first guess is read before the loop and is never counted. Also, if the first guess is correct, the loop never runs and `c` remains 0 even though the user made 1 guess. Correct counting requires incrementing when each guess is made (including the first), or initializing `c` to 1 after reading the first guess, or restructuring to read inside the loop and increment each time.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output for the number of guesses (e.g., prints 0 when the first guess is correct; otherwise prints one less than expected).

evidence.code_snippet: b=s.nextInt(); // first guess happens here, but c is not incremented

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Automatic Input Reading Without Explicit Assignment
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that after printing the prompt and feedback messages inside the loop, the program will automatically read the next user input into variable `b` without needing to explicitly call `s.nextInt()` again. They think the loop will somehow get fresh input on each iteration to update `b` and check the condition.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student does not understand that variables retain their values across loop iterations unless explicitly reassigned. In Java, `s.nextInt()` must be called each time you want to read a new input; printing a prompt does not trigger input reading. The variable `b` is assigned exactly once (line 11) and never updated inside the loop body, so the condition `b!=a` will either always be true (infinite loop) or always be false.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: If the first guess is incorrect, the program enters an infinite loop because `b` never changes. The user will see the feedback message repeated infinitely without being asked for a new guess. If the first guess is correct, the program exits immediately with 0 guesses counted.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that the variable 'b' is permanently 'linked' to the Scanner's input stream because it was assigned 's.nextInt()' once. They expect that every time the loop condition 'b != a' is checked, the machine will automatically pull a new value from the user to see if it has changed.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: Java follows an imperative execution model where variables are static storage locations. A variable only changes its value when an explicit assignment (=) is executed. The computer does not 're-read' the input during the loop condition check; the assignment must be explicitly repeated within the loop body to fetch new user input.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes the variable 'c' serves as a global tracker for the 'concept' of guessing, and that 'c++' inside the loop will account for the initial guess made outside the loop.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In the Java Notional Machine, instructions are executed strictly in the order they are reached in the control flow. If the user's first guess is correct, the 'while' condition 'b!=a' is immediately false, and the machine skips the loop body entirely. Consequently, the increment 'c++' is never executed, and the program will report that the user took 0 guesses.
